ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
- I learned the core concepts of linear algebra
- I learned about matrices, the null space, eigenvectors, eigenvalues, and many other concepts
More about linear algebra, its applications, and logistic things
Knowledge of linear algebra with applications.
Learned fundamental concepts of Linear Algebra and problem solving abilities.
I learned a great deal about vectors, matrices, and their many applications, including Gaussian elimination, spaces, projections, and eignenpairs.
This course covers the foundations of linear algebra, including concepts such as eigenvectors and matrix math.
Various applications of vector geometry and matrix algebra such as projections and their connection to OLS regression.

I learned computational skills in matrix operations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, linear transformations, bases, determinants, and other fundamental linear algebra topics. I also developed problem solving skills in having to connect different properties together.
absolutely nothing
We learned about properties of matrices and linear transformations, properties of subspaces, matrix decomposition, eigen values and eigenvectors, as well as determinants.
I learned a lot about how to utilize matrices in various contexts.

I learned much of linear algebra, such as the properties of matrices, how to do matrix multiplication, projection matrices, transformation matrices, subspaces, orthogonal matrices, projection matrices, eigenvectors, and eigenvalues.
I guess I learned linear algebra
Basic linear algebra concepts: matrix manipulations & properties, transformations, projection, etc.
The class entailed many different approaches towards understanding major concepts of linear algebra both in the form of proofs and application-based problems.

- Vector and matrix operations
- Inverse and transpose matrices
- Vector spaces
- Determinants
- Eigenvectors and eigenvalues
- Eigen decomposition of matrices
Matrices, eigenvalues, decomposition, determinants, fundamental subspaces
Linear algebra skills

This course gave me a good foundation in linear algebra. I gained extensive experience in working with matrices and gained a good understanding about subspaces and their applications. The course provided a deeper understanding into the workings of linear equations, and the application focus of the course offered insight into how the concepts of linear algebra are applied in various problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
- the material was interesting and I enjoyed the problem sets
- some concepts could be explained more slowly, more examples of concepts could be provided
Grading is very harsh, but content is clear and many resources are available
It's difficult as it's a lecture course which I feel is not an ideal way to learn math. Large class size, too, which is difficult.

Strengths were that material and lecture direction were all well structured as well as well as review sessions and problem sets. Weaknesses were that the lectures were not very engaging and the office hours kept moving around.

I think this course was excellent. I would not say there were any weaknesses. The professor did an excellent job making lecture interesting each and every class. Assignments were very informative but also fairly short and doable. The tests were super fair as well. If you study hard, you will perform great in this course.

This course was generally well organized, but I found homework to be much easier than exams. I don't think this is a problem with the course, but perhaps indicates that more could be offered to students to help prepare for exams.
Teaching quality and feedback was not clear. Much easier to learn concepts on my own rather than in actual class

I appreciated the recap at the beginning of each class, it was very helpful in retaining concepts and transitioning into the next one. However, the strict unforgiving deadlines added a lot of unnecessary stress.
I found the material pretty straightforward and the problem sets were helpful in reinforcing the material. I did find the MIT opencourseware lectures to explain the concepts more clearly.

This class has no strength: The instruction is unclear and unrelated to either problem sets or exams, making it virtually useless to go to lectures. Most of the study has to be done by the student via online sources, and this seems to be the case across sections. The Office Hours are sparse and confusing, as TA's change location and availability frequently. Even though this class is supposed to be "with Applications," there is zero amount of application of linear algebra to real world scenarios, unlike ENAS 151. This is an extremely dry course that puts an excessive emphasis on tedious computation and in fact tests it.

Strengths: the problems sets are very straightforward and do not take that much time to do; Professor Landa is also a good teacher who explains concepts in linear algebra very thoroughly and clearly. Compared to MATH 225, this class is much easier from what I've heard.
Weaknesses: there could be more examples of applications of linear algebra to fields like signal analysis, computer science, or anything else. For a class titled "Linear Algebra with Applications," there were not that many applications mentioned in class. This is also not explicitly a con, but beware that the tests contain a True/False section which requires you to think a lot more abstractly to solve its problems, which the problem sets don't really train you to do.
Sometimes the order of topics taught felt somewhat haphazard (e.g. switching topics and then going back to previous ones) and it made it a little confusing.

Strengths: clear lectures, straightforward problem sets and exams 

Weaknesses: lectures weren't super engaging and there wasn't much discussion of applications
This class was taught fairly well; the problem sets were very helpful practice. However, I think less time in class could have been spent on reviewing what was covered in the previous lecture.

I thought that the content was overall pretty interestingwell taught as well. I think that the course moved a bit quickly at times, especially for those without a solid background knowledge in matrices.

This is the worst course by the worst instructor I have ever taken. I should have heeded CourseTable before choosing to take it.  Professor Landa is incredibly unaccommodating to students and does not seem to have a passion for teaching.

The class covered all of the topics of linear algebra in detail. Office hours, review sessions, and practice problems were available, which were very useful in learning and studying for tests. The class could be improved by including practice problems every once in a while during lectures to keep students engaged. It could also be improved by either giving some supplemental information on how to do proofs or decreasing the number of proof questions on the problem sets, because it was hard to do those problems when the technique for writing a proof was never explained.

This class was recorded and also posted helpful class materials. It followed a fairly straightforward order of topics, and was a logical progression that built off itself. Boris started with good reviews (probably too long) in every class. Worst part of the class was that it was quite unengaging.

Strengths: less intense (but still sufficient, I think) linear algebra class. clear lectures and problem sets

Weaknesses: all or nothing grading for True / False questions on exams is frustratinga) most were fair, but some asked conceptual questions I felt unequipped to answer despite feeling comfortable with psets & practice exams, b) I wish I didn't have to seek outside guidance to figure out the right justification when I got a T/F wrong. They just seemed like the least fair questions, often.
I wish those conceptual questions were asked in short answer / application type contexts (even if I recognize how T/F might make grading easier)

Please better attempt to return all relevant problem sets before the midterms that cover the same information. I only received grades for 2/4 problem sets before midterm 1 (both which were much easier than psets 3/4), and made preventable mistakes I could have avoided with feedback on 3 & 4.
Great course with phenomenal instructors who were constantly engaged with the class and its material.

Strengths: 
- There was a helpful review of the previous lecture's material at the beginning of each lecture.

Weaknesses: 
- Course organization could be improved
- Division of course topics not totally clear
- Insufficient accommodation for students who are unable to take exams as scheduled

Lectures sometimes hard to follow
Strength: course follows textbook well

The most glaring weakness of this course is the lack of communication regarding testing material. As the course does not follow the textbook directly, we were (upon request from our instructor) declined a list of topics or a summary of materials that we would be tested on. Because of this, review sessions were not always comprehensive. This made preparing for finals and midterms difficult. However, I would say that problem sets were usually a fair representation of material covered in class.
Too fast paced, needs to go more in depth as to how and why everything works

The strengths of this course are its wide range of topics covered and its focus on applications. The amount of topics covered really helped build an all-around foundation in linear algebra. That variety allowed students to experience various concepts of that area of mathematics and it really provided a good overview to what linear algebra is about. As for the focus on applications, it made the concepts learned in class more approachable as personally, I could understand how I could use what I learned in every day problems that I might see. However, I think that the goal to cover many topics made it so that the understanding of some of those topics was more shallow. I felt that oftentimes, not enough time was spent on explaining why a certain concept worked the way that it did, and so it made applying those concepts to questions more difficult. As this course if not proofs-based, I think one thing that could be helpful would be having more in-class examples of concepts in problems to help students better see those concepts from various angles. Another aspect of the class that could be improved would be providing an overview or schedule of the topics that students learn. During the semester, I felt that it was at times difficult to see where certain concepts fit into what was already previously learned, and so I think having some sort of guide to the semester would be very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: - Yes, it gives a solid math foundation which allows you to pursue further math courses
I would only take this if you have to for your major. Isnt a great time but could be worse.
I wouldn't recommend this course. I believe the material is interesting, but it is set up poorly.
Only recommend if you are interested in math itself and want to learn linear algebra or if you need it to further your major or as a prereq for another class.

Yes. This is possibly my favorite course at Yale. You learn a great deal throughout the semester, and these things likely apply to other work you will be doing in STEM. The teacher is excellent as well. In terms of workload, it is super manageable. I actually found these problem sets to be fun, and I thought the tests were something you could prepare very well for given the resources provided to you.
Yes, genuinely very interesting subject matter with various applications in various fields.
No, unless required. Least favorite class I have had here.
Its a good introductory linear algebra course. Im not sure where the applications in the title of the course come from as I dont think we covered any.

I would never recommend this course to another student, and I should hope no one take this course ever in the future. To pre-empt the argument that I might be leaving such hideous comments because of my lack of preparation in mathematics, this is simply not the case: I got A's in MATH 115 and ENAS 151, and I come to this class with confidence. I am never the math genius but have always tried to put in the hard work. Yet this class has failed me horrendously. I simply don't believe that this class is right for anyone.
I would recommend this course if you want to learn about linear algebra and are going to use it for future work. Professor Landa is a good teacher who explains concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Yes, if you like math but want to avoid proof-based classes.
Only under diff teachers

I would recommend this to a student who just wants a computational understanding of linear algebra. I took this course simply because I wanted a little exposure to linear algebra out of my own curiosity, so I didn't have really high stakes for needing to understand the material on a conceptual level, which is why I felt this class was a good fit for me. For those who are looking for a greater challenge or who need to actually use linear algebra in the future, I would suggest looking at a different course.
This class is good at teaching you the basics of linear algebra. However, this class did not cover many practical applications of any of the material we learned.
I wouldI thought it was a decent introduction to linear algebra without getting bogged down by the proofs. Im glad that I took the class even though all of the reviews advised against it.
No. Please wait until it's taught by someone else.
I would only recommend if it is a requirement for you, or if you want to improve your computational skills.
If you need it, this linear is (from what Ive heard) easier than 225, though somewhat less interesting. Depends what you need out of your semester.
Sure, if they needed a linear algebra credit. But lectures were just ok, and psets were less engaging than for other math classes.
I would recommend this course to any student which is interested in gaining a stronger foundation in linear algebra's principles.

I chose this class over MATH 225 because it is an "applications" class. We did not do any examples involving linear algebra applied to real-world scenarios in this class. But, if you don't like writing mathematical proofs this class is still probably a better option.
Not unless you have to, I was bored throughout most of it

If you want/need to learn linear algebra and you do not have the time to take 225, as I didn't, then I would recommend this course (as it is really the only option, and you will gain exposure to important topics). If you really have an interest in linear algebra and it will be important to your major, then I would not recommend this class.
Yes, needs to be done

I would recommend this course to a student who is looking to gain an all-around understanding of linear algebra. The course covers a wide range of topics and shows how those concepts can be applied in various problems, so at the end of the semester, the student will be able to use linear algebra in other disciplines as well.
